#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=The ANDRILL team almost failed to get any samples at all .
#Text=Designed to examine the seafloor , the ROV had to be inverted to examine the roof of ice .

#Text=Weather conditions prevented biological sampling equipment being delivered from McMurdo Station , but the scientists retrieved 20 – 30 anemones by using hot water to stun them before sucking them from their burrows with an improvised device fashioned from a coffee filter and a spare ROV thruster .
#Text=Preserved on-site in ethanol , they were taken to McMurdo station where some were further preserved with formaldehyde .
#Text=This map shows the location of the Ross Ice Shelf in the Antarctic , and the two known localities for E. andrillae relative to McMurdo Station Image : Daly et al.
#Text=( ( Wikinews ) ) How did you come to be involved with this discovery ?
#Text=Marymegan
#Text=Daly
#Text=:
#Text=Frank Rack got in touch after they returned from Antarctica in hopes that I could help with an identification on the anemone .
#Text=( ( Wikinews ) ) What was your first reaction upon learning there was an undiscovered ecosystem under the ice in the Ross Sea ?
#Text=MD I was amazed and really excited .
#Text=I think to say it was unexpected is inaccurate , because it implies that there was a well-founded expectation of something .

#Text=The technology that Frank and his colleagues are using to explore the ice is so important because , given our lack of data , we have no reasonable expectation of what it should be like , or what it should n't be like .
#Text=( ( Wikinews ) ) There 's a return trip planned hopefully for 2015 , with both biologists and ANDRILL geologists .
#Text=Are you intending to go there yourself ?
#Text=MD I would love to .
#Text=But I am also happy to not go , as long as someone collects more animals on my behalf !
#Text=What I want to do with the animals requires new material preserved in diverse ways , but it does n't require me to be there .

#Text=Although I am sure that being there would enhance my understanding of the animals and the system in which they live , and would help me formulate more and better questions about the anemones , ship time is expensive , especially in Antarctica , and if there are biologists whose contribution is predicated on being there , they should have priority to be there .
#Text=( ( Wikinews ) )
#Text=These animals are shrouded in mystery .
#Text=Some of the most intriguing questions are chemical ; do they produce some kind of antifreeze , and is that orange glow in the ROV lights their own ?
#Text=Talk us through the difficulties encountered when trying to find answers with the specimens on hand .
#Text=MD
#Text=The samples we have are small in terms of numbers and they are all preserved in formalin ( a kind of formaldehyde solution ) .
#Text=The formalin is great for preserving structures , but for anemones , it prevents study of DNA or of the chemistry of the body .
#Text=This means we ca n't look at the issue you raise with these animals .

#Text=What we could do , however , was to study anatomy and figure out what it is , so that when we have samples preserved for studying e. g. , the genome , transcriptome , or metabolome , or conduct tests of the fluid in the burrows or in the animals themselves , we can make precise comparisons , and figure out what these animals have or do ( metabolically or chemically ) that lets them live where they live .
